The temperature in low earth orbit is 120°C and life is impossible without shade of some kind. The ISS and Skylab both used and use solar arrays as shades, and parasol shields.
Going out doors in sunny weather should be done with proper precautions, put on a hat, slap on some screen and don't forget the sunglasses. Your shades have some numbers on them which tells you the level of protection they offer. UV light is harmful as the wavelength, in nano meters, decreases, and frequency, Hertz, increases.
The higher you go the less atmopshere protects you. As you climb out of low earth orbit the radiation from the solar wind trapped in the magnetosphere increases in strength for about 1000 miles above the surface of the planet before begining to diminish.
Scientists attempted to dispel this belt of radiation by blasting the stratosphere with 2053 nuclear bombs in the first two years of the 1960s.
The idea was to neutralise the B or magetic field intensity through the nuclear Electro Magnetic Pulse.
This was based on a poor understanding of the physics and was more experimental than anything. It did not work and actually backfired, creating more radiation and a new low orbit belt which destroyed all the satalites then in orbit, after 5 years exposure.
So man has never been able to travel beyond the karman line, beyond the atmosphere.

The term "Great Britain" is a bit confusing though, because historically it referred to the sovereign nation of the United Kingdom (the UK these days is still often called "Britain" for short), as well as the island. In fact, Britain's Olympic team is still called "Team GB" (Team Great Britain). And Britain's 3-letter ISO country code is "GBR" (which we put on stickers on our cars). So even a Northern Irish driver would put "GBR" on their car.

Furthermore, the term "country" when it comes to the UK can also be weird. In the UK we say that England, Scotland, and Wales are "countries", but they're not sovereign states such as the UK itself, or France, Germany, etc. So perhaps Britain should refer to England, Scotland, and Wales are provinces, or territories, or states, which is effectively what they are, using terminology used by other countries (like Canada in the case of provinces, or US in the case of states, etc.). But we don't call them provinces or states and most likely never will. We'll keep calling them countries, even though they're not actually full-blown countries (they're not sovereign states), they're just parts of the country that is known as the UK / Britain.

This information on how the moon was formed is a little old now (2016). It's not far off in that there was a collision, but the most recent theory is that both planets turned molten on collision and that the rotation caused a big lump to sort of roll off before it cooled. Modern simulations also show potential for a fairly large iron core in the moon. The previous theory of debris forming the moon was flawed which is why they continued to look for alternatives. The most recent theory settles all the flaws but as with all science, they are always open to new ideas.

That's the thing, we're all living on essentially a graveyard. Not only the fact that there are billions of unknown people and animals decomposing below your feet and the remains floating in the air, the coffee you drank this morning may have water that filtered through the kidney of a Roman Centurion or a t-Rex. This planet itself is the remains from a previous star. Think of all the materials that make you into you: Carbon, oxygen, iron as example. Even in the rest of the world, Cesium, Uranium, and on...

None of those elements could have been created in the Big Bang, only in the core of a star for billions of years worth of fusion. At one point that star had to have exploded, seeding its surrounding area with the elements we take for granted here on Earth. Even the core of our planet isn't hot enough to create these new material naturally, it just keeps it in a liquid state. So a star had to die in order for us to live. We're all star-stuff, but from a long dead and forgotten body.

here is a funny fact.
Thea, the planet that we believe hit the earth in the past, thus creating the Moon. Here in this video is been pronounced thEa (with the intonation at the "E" letter) but the word should instead be pronounced theA ! (with the intonation at the "A" letter at the end). Why is that so?
Well, the word Thea comes from the Greek word Θεα (Th=Θ, e=ε, a=α Θ ε ά) which means Goddess! Thea means Goddess in Greek and because in Greek the intonation goes to where the intonation mark is (the intonation mark in the word Θεά is in the "ά" letter) the word in Greek is being pronounced theA and not thEa!
and because the word Thea is exactly the same word from the Greeks Θεά. The intonation of the word Thea in this video is totally wrong.

that happens every time you pronounce a Greek word in English. That happens, because the people who "translated" the words, didn't real translate anything, they just placed latin letters to the corresponding Greek letters and never really cared about the intonation marks (that in Greek words indicate where the intonation should go) making every single Greek word you spell COMPLETELY wrong from its original :/

Any true scientist will NEVER say that there is no god... at least, of course, until, if ever, any evidence to hint at that idea is ever discovered. The absense of evidence isn't evidence of absence. There is absolutely no reason for anyone to say that a god does not exist. This is because there is no disputable evidence either for or against the theory.

First of all, scientists don't "prove" anything. Nor do they try to "disprove" anything. In science, nothing is ever 100% correct. New evidence is constantly being found and used to expand or even roll back current theories. Science is an art of observation and deduction. Scientists draw theories FROM evidence, not evidence from theories. It is counter productive to specifically look for "evidence" to support an idea. That's called having a bias and is the bane of all scientific progress.

You don't "make up" math formulas... Symbols used in math are used to denote specific ideas and trains of thought and action. They do not change and they aren't created to "prove" anything. They are merely symbols for ideas just like letters of the alphabet. For example, the number 2 denotes the idea of having, among other things, two different things. You can count them: 1, 2. Then if you had another 2 things to count, you can continue the first count by 3 and 4. Therefore, 2+2=4.

We wouldn't have seasons as they exist today. Seasons are caused by the angle of direct sunlight hitting the face of the Earth. It has little to do with the distance of Earth to the sun. Case and point, the Earth is actually further away from the sun in summer than it is in spring and fall. The reason why, in the Northern hemisphere, that it is hot in the summer, is because the rays of the sun are striking the surface of the Earth at the most direct angle.

And as the disk revolves the gasses it contains will start to condense as they move around and come closer to each other. This will make smaller balls of dense gas that will still revolve around the larger ball in the center. As they go around they'll in time have picked up all/most of the gas. These balls over time condense more and more. In our example the ball in the center burst into a star, while the rest formed different kinds of planets when the density became to high.

@nikoinlc This will then cause the surrounding gasses to be pulled towards this center, which will grow into a large massive ball. If the nebula's big and/or dense enough, it'll be able to form a solar system. Other times it'll only form stars. But as this ball grows bigger, a larger area of gas around it will be pulled towards it. It'll not move in a straight line but in a spiral. This will eventually cause a huge disc of gas revolving around this center.
